questions.content: Let us fill in the gaps -

sub_questions.content: Oblique sides of isosceles trapezium are ____ [equal/unequal].
solution: In an isosceles trapezium, the non-parallel sides (oblique sides) are equal in length by definition.

sub_questions.content: If two pairs of opposite sides of a trapezium are equal it is a ____.
solution: A trapezium has at least one pair of parallel sides. If a quadrilateral has two pairs of equal opposite sides, it is a parallelogram. A parallelogram is a special case of a trapezium.

sub_questions.content: Opposite sides of a parallelogram are mutually ____ [parallel/not parallel].
solution: By definition, a parallelogram is a quadrilateral with two pairs of parallel opposite sides.

sub_questions.content: If one angle of a parallelogram is 90°, then it will be ____ [Rectangle/Rhombus].
solution: A parallelogram with one right angle is a rectangle. In a parallelogram, consecutive angles are supplementary, so if one is 90°, all angles must be 90°.
A diagonal is a line segment that connects two non-consecutive vertices. A quadrilateral has 4 vertices, and it has exactly 2 diagonals.

sub_questions.content: Diagonals of a rhombus bisect each other at ____.
solution: A key property of a rhombus is that its diagonals are perpendicular bisectors of each other. This means they intersect at a 90° angle.

sub_questions.content: The opposite sides of a rectangle are ____ [equal/unequal].
solution: A rectangle is a parallelogram, and a fundamental property of parallelograms is that opposite sides are equal in length.

sub_questions.content: Rhombus is a special type of ____ [square/ parallel].
solution: A rhombus is a parallelogram with four equal sides. The option 'parallel' likely refers to a parallelogram. A square is a special type of rhombus, but every rhombus is a special type of parallelogram.

sub_questions.content: The diagonals of a parallelogram ____ each other.
solution: A property of all parallelograms is that their diagonals bisect each other, meaning they intersect at their midpoints.
